items.title: Serpent 1.30 does not work with Python 2.7
items.body:
Yesterday our production codebase started to fail:

21:17:52.932 	DEBUG 	[ PIXIE ] Traceback (most recent call last): 	
21:17:52.932 	DEBUG 	[ PIXIE ]   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/runpy.py", line 174, in _run_module_as_main 	
21:17:52.933 	DEBUG 	[ PIXIE ]     "__main__", fname, loader, pkg_name) 	
21:17:52.933 	DEBUG 	[ PIXIE ]   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/runpy.py", line 72, in _run_code 	
21:17:52.934 	DEBUG 	[ PIXIE ]     exec code in run_globals 	
21:17:52.934 	DEBUG 	[ PIXIE ]   File "/home/pi/workspace/septentrio/pixie.py", line 25, in <module> 	
21:17:52.935 	DEBUG 	[ PIXIE ]     import serpent 	
21:17:52.935 	DEBUG 	[ PIXIE ]   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/serpent.py", line 56, in <module> 	
21:17:52.936 	DEBUG 	[ PIXIE ]     from collections.abc import KeysView, ValuesView, ItemsView 	
21:17:52.936 	DEBUG 	[ PIXIE ] ImportError: No module named abc

Turns out serpent is trying to import collections.abc which does not exist in Python 2.7.

Is this a bug?

items.title: ValueError: Couldn't import 'kombu.transport.pyro:Transport': invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'dev0
items.body:
This is already fixed in master, however I don't see that a new version of serpent has been released since 1.30.0. We have some code that uses serpent and is failing on import with:

```
    try:
        import serpent
        if '-' in serpent.__version__:
            ver = serpent.__version__.split('-', 1)[0]
        else:
            ver = serpent.__version__
>       ver = tuple(map(int, ver.split(".")))
E       ValueError: Couldn't import 'kombu.transport.pyro:Transport': invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'dev0'
```

This is due to:
`serpent.py:__version__ = "1.30.dev0"`

As a work-around I'm going to patch the ubuntu package with:
`serpent.py:__version__ = "1.30"`

items.title: Test files in sdist archive mssing
items.body: Could you please add unittests to sdist archive on pypi? Distributions try to execute tests on the package to verify the reverse dependencies didn't break it. Without tests python packages are basically just `cp target destination` and with that we can't be sure if it really at least basically works.

items.title: License file in pypi archive
items.body: The pypi source archive isn't including the `LICENSE` file. Would it be possible to add it? It is very helpful when packaging this for Linux distributions. Thank you.

items.title: Serializing properties
items.body:
Hi,

Is there a way to make sure serpent serializes properties as well by default? Some of the proxy objects returned by remote calls I use have properties resulting in an error like

    TypeError: don't know how to serialize class <type 'property'>

I would prefer to avoid adapter classes but I don't know if this is possible.

Thanks!

items.title: uuid.UUID objects are not correctly loaded
items.body:
@irmen  serpent is not correctly deserializing  the uuid.UUID object. It returns a string instead of an UUID object.
The following code reproduces the issue.

```
>>> import uuid
>>> import serpent
>>> x = uuid.uuid4()
>>> b = serpent.dumps(x)
>>> y = serpent.loads(b)
>>> y == x
False
>>> type(y)
<class 'str'>
```

items.title: Why namedtuple is parsed as tuple?
items.body:
collections.namedtuple and tuple are quite different, I'm quite confused that why the serilized namedtuple becomes tuple?

```
>>> import serpent
>>> import collections
>>> Point=collections.namedtuple('Point', list('xyz'))
>>> pt=Point(1,2,3)
>>> serpent.dumps(pt)
'# serpent utf-8 python2.6\n(1,2,3)'
>>> serpent.loads(_)
(1, 2, 3)
```

items.title: java9 compile fails due to JAXB not available by default
items.body:
java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: javax/xml/bind/DatatypeConverter
        at net.razorvine.serpent.Serializer.serialize_calendar(Serializer.java:437)

JAXB is no longer available in JDK 9 by default.
Replace JAXB dependency with something else to encode/decode base-64 data.

items.title: accept memoryview to deserializes
items.body: should accept memoryview to deserialize

items.title: problems serializing str with \x00
items.body:
When serializing a str with \x00 in it from java/jython, the resulting serpent data still contains the 0-byte.
It will crash upon deserializing because ast.literal_eval can't deal with this.

It ALSO crashes when trying the same with a unicode string from python 2.7 using normal python serpent!

Originally reported as https://github.com/irmen/Pyro4/issues/152

items.title: java: don't crash on Jython types
items.body:
The java Serpent library crashes with infinite nesting when used from Jython directly, when passing certain types such as tuples, bytearray etc. Jython passes them as internal objects of type ``org.python.core.Something`` and serpent doesn't recognise these yet.

Fix: teach Serpent (the java lib) about these types.

This will fix the issue reported here https://github.com/irmen/Pyro4/issues/149   (which is not a problem in Pyro)

items.title: complex number deserialization problems
items.body: java and .net have bugs in the complex number deserializer that can cause parser errors if floats are used in complex numbers

items.title: support enum type
Python + Serpent: float serialization accuracy
items.body:
Hi,
When using Pyro4 with the default serpent serializer, I noticed that floats at the receiver side have a reduced 12-digit accuracy. For example:
```
SERPENT: 
1482514078.55
Original
1482514078.546359
```
It seems that in ser_builtins_float in serpent.py, a float is converted as follows:
`out.append(str(float_obj).encode("ascii"))`
while for full accuracy it should be like:
`out.append("{:f}".format(float_obj).encode("ascii"))`

Thanks for checking.

Edit:
> Python versions prior to 3.2 use 12 digits for the whole number when using str().
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20586011/python-precision-in-string-formatting-with-float-numbers

items.title: make .net code more portable
items.body:
hashtable, arraylist  -> dictionary<T,T>, list<T>

class with DataContract attribute instead of Serializable should also be properly serialized

items.title: make the .net library targeting a .NET standard version so it works on .net core too
Please merge the Pull Request to serialize datetime.date
items.body:
Hi Irmen,

Serpent fails to serialize datetime.date objects:

```
>>> import serpent
>>> import datetime
>>> serpent.dumps(datetime.date.today())
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/serpent.py", line 78, in dumps
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/serpent.py", line 250, in serialize
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/serpent.py", line 291, in _serialize
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/serpent.py", line 551, in ser_default_class
TypeError: don't know how to serialize class <type 'datetime.date'>. Give it vars() or an appropriate __getstate__
```

[My pull request](https://github.com/irmen/Serpent/pull/15) adds the appropriate method and unit tests. Would you please review and merge it soon? Logistically, when would pip have the latest build if you chose to merge this?

Thanks and best regards. --Matthew Moisen

items.title: be able to automatically serialize dict_keys etc
items.body: For python3; be able to automatically serialize dict_keys types and other iterables that were sets in python2   (dict.keys() etc)

items.title: parsing large lists of numbers is very inefficent
items.body:
SeekableStringReader.readUntil is very inefficient in the java code.

When deserializing a large (20000+) array of floats, it takes many seconds to process this and most of the time is spent in readUntil().

(.Net version is alsp slow, even though it uses a more efficient search method on the string type)

items.title: Maven build fails with JDK 1.7
doesn't handle +inf, -inf and Nan very well
items.body:
has problems converting java's Double.NaN, Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY and Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY to serialized form that Python understands.  It receives "NaN" , "Infinity" and "-Infinity" and those are not correct literal expressions in Python for the corresponding floating point number. Hence the crash in ast.parse_eval with ValueError: malformed node or string: <_ast.Name object at 0x03F713B0>

Haven'nt looked at C# yet.

The other way around should probably work as well (python -> java/c#)

items.title: Support for a dictionary expression with a trailing comma?
items.body:
I am trying to use the Java version of Serpent for parsing the header of [NPY files](http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-dev/neps/npy-format.html).

A header looks something like this: `{'descr': '<i8', 'fortran_order': False, 'shape': (1,), }`. Serpent fails to parse this header string because of the trailing comma:

```
Exception in thread "main" net.razorvine.serpent.ParseException: invalid int character (at position 56; '...lse, 'shape': (1,), >>><<<}...')
        at net.razorvine.serpent.Parser.parse(Parser.java:60)
Caused by: net.razorvine.serpent.ParseException: invalid int character
        at net.razorvine.serpent.Parser.parseInt(Parser.java:320)
        at net.razorvine.serpent.Parser.parseSingle(Parser.java:310)
        at net.razorvine.serpent.Parser.parseExpr(Parser.java:79)
        at net.razorvine.serpent.Parser.parseKeyValue(Parser.java:190)
        at net.razorvine.serpent.Parser.parseKeyValueList(Parser.java:182)
        at net.razorvine.serpent.Parser.parseDict(Parser.java:261)
        at net.razorvine.serpent.Parser.parseCompound(Parser.java:99)
        at net.razorvine.serpent.Parser.parseExpr(Parser.java:77)
        at net.razorvine.serpent.Parser.parse(Parser.java:53)
        ... 3 more
```

I can solve this issue by applying the following patchfile, but from the grammar perspective, this is clearly a sub-optimal solution:

```
diff --git a/java/src/main/java/net/razorvine/serpent/Parser.java b/java/src/main/java/net/razorvine/serpent/Parser.java
index 8265531..1eec774 100644
--- a/java/src/main/java/net/razorvine/serpent/Parser.java
+++ b/java/src/main/java/net/razorvine/serpent/Parser.java
@@ -179,6 +179,10 @@ public class Parser
        while(sr.hasMore() && sr.peek()==',')
        {
            sr.read();
+           sr.skipWhitespace();
+           if(sr.peek() == '}'){
+               break;
+           }
            kvs.add(parseKeyValue(sr));
        }
        return kvs;
```

Does the Python grammar allow the trailing comma here?

If this is simply a quirk of the NPY file format, then I should probably replace `, }` at the end of the header string with `}`, and everything will be fine.

items.title: Dictionary size changed during iteration
items.body:
Every now and then, when calling Serpent (via Pyro), I get "Dictionary size changed during iteration" exception.

It comes from line 238 to 241 (_serialize method) in serpent.py (version 1.7):

```
    for clazz in _special_classes_registry:
        if isinstance(obj, clazz):
            _special_classes_registry[clazz](obj, self, out, level)
            return
```

It seems that if the if-block returns true, the exception will get thrown.  I don't know why it doesn't always happen.

items.title: Custom Serializers?
items.body:
As I mentioned (in passing) [elsewhere](https://github.com/irmen/Pyro4/issues/39), I'd like to pass a class derived from `email.message.Message` across a Pyro4 link.  In memory, it includes problematic cyclical references that kills the serializer.  However, both `Message` and the derived class (`PyzMessage`) have perfectly good `as_string()` representations.

The [Pyro4 docs](https://pythonhosted.org/Pyro4/api/util.html#Pyro4.util.SerializerBase.register_dict_to_class) talk about registering `class_to_dict()` and `dict_to_class()` functions.  Unfortunately, the latter (`dict_to_class`) doesn't seem to exist.  Am I missing something?
# 

If I'm not missing something, then I believe a follow-up line of questions are appropriate.  Before I found `dict_to_class` mentioned, I discovered an `ast` [walk-through](http://greentreesnakes.readthedocs.org/en/latest/nodes.html) and [helper file](https://bitbucket.org/takluyver/greentreesnakes/src/c353f21f1bb89834b9838e4a6dd475dc593e67f1/astpp.py?at=default) that (if I'm not mistaken) shows you how to generate an `ast` representation that would eval into an actual instance of the class (initialized with the desired data).

For example, an instance of `PyzMessage` with the `as_string()` representation `<string representation>` could be constructed using the following expression:

```
pyzmail.message_from_string("<string representation>")
```

which translates (at least using their default settings) to:

```
Module(body=[
    Expr(value=Call(func=Attribute(value=Name(id='pyzmail', ctx=Load()), attr='message_from_string', ctx=Load()), args=[
        Str(s='<string representation>'),
      ], keywords=[], starargs=None, kwargs=None)),
  ])
```

Any idea if a serializer like this would produce instances like I would want?  Especially if dict_to_class doesn't exist, are you aware of any pitfalls of this approach?

items.title: unparsable string can be generated in ironpython
items.body:
In Pyro4: when ironpython uses serpent to serialize a server-side exception with traceback, an unparsable string is generated.
It contains embedded newlines that break the string literals.

items.title: tag 1.2
items.body:
irmen,

I am using your Pyro4 module, which requires Serpent (as you well know).  I am on a Mac system for which I am writing a Portfile for the MacPorts package management system to be able to automatically install dependencies.  One option of the Portfile is to be able to indicate that the source should be downloaded from github via a tag.  However, the version 1.2 tag does not exist for Serpent here on github, whereas there is a 1.2 version of serpent on pypi.  Can you please tag your repository at the same commit where that pypi version was released?

Thanks,
Sterling
